content.description:
Ylem is a powerful lowball that ascends a thirty degree overhang on good edges.

Sit start with a left hand edge and right hand sidepull. From there, make a big right hand move to a big edge, rein the feet in, hit a left hand edge, then work the lip and sloping bumps to top it out.
content.protection: A pad or two should be good. The landing has a rock behind the problem, but it doesn't pose much of a risk.
content.location: It climbs the overhanging south face of Milquetoast.

content.description:
Sit start with a right hand pinch on the arete and a left hand three-finger pocket. From there, stick a left hand edge, match a hand next to it, match on the large shelf above it, then work the remaining pantina to top it out.

The upper edges/patina haven't been thoroughly vetted, be cautious on what you pull on.
content.protection: A pad or two will work just fine, the landing is very good.
content.location: It climbs the north arete of Milquetoast.

content.description:
Stand start with hands matched on an incut edge five feet off the deck. From there, work straight up the face on excellent incut edges/crimps/jugs.

Beware, the upper portion of the problem is riddled with thin patina edges that are friable.
content.protection: A pad should work fine. The landing is excellent.
content.location: It climbs the center of Milquetoast's northeast face.
